transcript.content: Allen Pharr Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Would you mind starting by stating your name?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah, my name is Allen Pharr. I was born in April 28th, 1964. Unfortunately, I committed a crime in 1986, second degree murder, armed robbery currently serving a life sentence here in Angola.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: At the time of my conviction, I just turned 22 and at that age, I don't think I was a matured adult. I don't know if I was going in a channel of peer pressure, or trying to hang with the joneses' or whatever the nature may be, but I made a mistake, man and committed a murder charge and I was like out for like a week or something and I walked right into the police station and turned myself in.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I was being wanted, armed and dangerous, and I walked right there, and they didn't even know who I was when I walked into the police station and turned myself in because I knew I had done wrong. And I come up, man. You know, my mom and my dad were separated periodically. I lived with at least one of them, but my childhood I lived with my grandmother and my grandfather, Georgiana and Dave Pharr.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Where did you grow up?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I grew up in Gibson, Louisiana. That's right outside of, that's Terrebonne Parish, but it's like eight miles outside of Houma, Louisiana. H-O-U-M-A.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Darrell Walkers is from there.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah that's right, that's my homeboy.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I really enjoyed talking with him.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah. He's real good. Me and his mom and real cool. And I went to H.L. Bousie High School, Evergreen Middle School, Greenwood Elementary school, and you know, up until my junior year in school, I was doing real good. I think I started hanging out with the wrong guys' man and trying to do the things of other people and not doing my own thing because I wasn't a dumb guy.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I got my work, had good academic scores in school, conduct record wasn't that bad but when I got to junior high, I got a little wild and smoking weed and doing everything that the crowd do, so I got kicked out because I got in a fight.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I joined Job Corp, went to Texas. Austin, Texas. I went to the biggest Job Corp in the United States. And it's Gary Job Corp in San Marcos, Texas. And I think Gary's the size of Angola, man, that's how big it is. Unfortunately, I got kicked out of there. I went with my cousin and he brought a Hitachi boom box with him and when we got there, unfortunately, he'd stole another guy's boom box. And tried to hit the tracks. The tracks is like here to St. Francis Ville, and that's 20 miles on the tracks.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: So, he tried to take it to the tracks and go sell it.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I said, "Man I just got here man, I ain't going on no tracks." So that morning when they tried to go, the security at the facility that we're at, Gary Job Corps as soon as they went across the street, the people came and apprehended them. So, I came to the station to try to help them.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I said, "Excuse me I'm here for Fredrick Hansey." And they had the box on the table. I said, "Look if you all let me get his box I will put it up for him until you let him go." They said, "Hold up, stay right there." Man they come back and tell me that dude said that I was with them when he stole the bike. I said, no man. And then they locked me up. The final verdict of that was as the facility said that we have to terminate ourselves or they will terminate us and if they terminate us we can't go to no more Job Corps, so I terminated myself.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old were you?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I was 19 then man. I was 19, then nineteen or 20 because a longest you could stay at job corps was 24. And at that time I think I was like 19, or 20. I come back home, I come back home man, and I ain't got a job.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let's go back a little bit earlier than that, I want you to tell me a little bit more about your grandparents. They were the ones that raised you?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah Georgiana and Dave. Yeah, they raised me. That was real quiet time for me. She was a real good baker and a cook, man. My grandfather he tended in the field. He would plant potatoes, corn you know Country. If you come to the steps of my grandmother's house, you're going to smell the potato pies coming through the front window. She's got to be singing.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: And we didn't really have no flowers in the yard we had the weeping willow tree, if you stand on it, you would think it was raining. That's the only thing she had in her front yard but you know man, it was a real quiet time. I think my grandfather was alive up to 102, years old, and my grandmother lived to be 88 years old. She dies first and then he died like two weeks after her. They ain't never been divorced or nothing. So I know their love is real, you know what I'm saying. I don't know man, I'll try to do is correct me. I do try to do that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can I ask you something? What's your last memory of your grandmother?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Wow.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: The last time you interacted with her…

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Well she had this thing. She had this silky gray hair. She always liked for me to comb her hair. I used to comb her hair. I ain't seen no hair like this. I mean it was real silky. You didn't have to fight through it, the comb would just go straight through it, and she was just really amazing. My grandfather, when he got in the 80s, so I had to bathe him and everything. At 102, he couldn't really do anything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember the last time you were with your grandmother?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Oh yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about that memory.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Well it's a real serenity memory, where I see that, she would be in the kitchen. This particular time I didn't like cabbage, the way it smelled. I'm telling you man, I just didn't like cabbage. And she made me eat that cabbage, bro, and I can vividly remember it.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I wasn't a vegetable person. And by her making me eat that cabbage, I just fell in love with all vegetables. And cabbage it was a hell of, she always cooked it, you know. By me eating the cabbage, I think you can see a pretty healthy guy, and I like to eat my vegetables bro. My grandmother man, she was my heart.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did she visit you here?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: No. Well unfortunately, they she passed before I got into all this trouble. Yeah, they passed before I got into this trouble. My father passed in '84 and my grandmother passed, in I think, '78, and my grandfather passed in '79 and my mother passed in 2008. I was here, but.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was your relationship like with your mother?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Oh it was good man, it was good. My mother, I respected my mother. Like I said, I come up, yes sir, no sir. I couldn't do no anything. But once I have 17-18, my mum, I couldn't smoke in front of her but she knew I smoked. She just didn't want me to do it in her presence. You know, she let me know, if I do something and I understood that. But my father man was in a different end, me and him, we sat around. We smoked, joked. He and me were cool. He was a real chef. He was like Chef Jeff, my father was real good at cooking.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I had a real good relationship with him, and down, they would just split.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Is it fair to say that you've up in a household where you felt loved and cared for?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Oh yes, indeed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you wouldn't characterize your childhood has something where you would where you were mistreated?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: No not at all, man. I remember my uncles, I remember me and my uncles used to come down, I get my uncles. All my uncles are deceased now, Freddy, Frank, Gideon, and David. They used all come over to my grandmother's house along with my father Elton, that's five. They used to like, one in Texas, one in California, three of them in New Orleans. So, they would always try to get us to come for vacation, school break or something, I will come with them. My mother had 12 kids, I'm the youngest of all them. I'm the only one that got in a mess. I'm the youngest.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Who visits you here?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I got a cousin in the military named Desiree Jordan. My uncle Frank, that's his daughter. And I met her, I didn't know she was my cousin. She was talking to my partner, who landed in here, named Bobby Wallace, he played Jesus I don't know if you've ever seen that documentary, they did a play it's called The Passion of the Christ, have you seen it?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: But anyways, Bobby, he does the Christ part. He was portraying Christ. So, one day he asks me what my name was, so I said "Allen Pharr." And a girl on the phone asked him to reach me the phone, and she said well, "What's your name?" I said "Allen Pharr." "Who are your people?" I went calling my uncles. She said, "Those are her uncles." I said, "What?" But that's how things happen, man.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I don't think is by mere chance or coincidence, everything happens for reason. And I'm a God-fearing man, and I've really become God-fearing since I've come to Angola. I come up going to Baptist Church, now I'm in nondenominational. I was raised Baptist. I seen where people go to church on Sundays, come out, not changed, they do the same thing.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Since I've come here, I knew that this change has got to happen. This change has to come. Jesus went everywhere, showing love, healing people, and the people couldn't understand it, man, it was just amazing. Even the disciples' man, the people that were close to him every day, seeing the miracles he was doing, couldn't understand. They didn't grasp the whole, I ain't saying, I'm working progress, man.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: And I will say that Jesus is the epitome of love. In this world right now we have a calamity of love, that people turn their back on God. When you turn your back on God, bad things happen. We see that through the course of the Bible, not to be religious and none of that. It's just the facts of life, you know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Let me ask you about some other things. What about girlfriends? Did you have one person particularly close to you before you got in here?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Well I wish I did, man. I had a lot of flings out there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you have any kids?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: No, unfortunately, at the age of 53, I have no kids, man. I hurt inside about that because my legacy, to pass my name on hopefully. I didn't really grasp that. I am not living in a fictitious mind. I'm realistic. And I will tell you that, if I was to pass right now, while talking to you, I know that I'm going home to see my grandmother and my grandfather again because they were Christ fearing Christians, man. They ain't play. That's my ultimate goal.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yes, I want to be a free man again but that's not, I know no more passing through. I took someone's life and I know that I'm going to die one day, and there is a life after this life. That's where I'm trying to get myself straight. I know I'm going to go through this life. I see God down here for entry. I try to mentor by passing by, meaning I don't want them to look at me like I'm a free man or something, I'm your brother.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I'm telling you that I've been year 31 years, man, you got the chance to be here for 18 months, get a trade and go back out there and do the right thing. You don't have to be doing no drugs, or stealing, or trying to do nothing. I am the only example. You're looking in the mirror right now. I shouldn't have to lead your hand or watch you. That should be enough motivation for you to get your life straight, you know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you find yourself mentoring the reentry guys quite a bit?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Well, when I come in contact with them, because you know I'm not.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I mean informally.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah like Pastor Walters. He's a mentor. He's in there with those guys but I'm affiliated with a lot of sports, just going by certain guys I might take a liking to, and holler at them because some will receive and some will reject.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. So, let's go back to the 22-year-old that you were some of these guys are like.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I always reflect on how I was, but at the age of 22, I wasn't rebellious, man. And respect was everything. Yes sir, no sir, I didn't get that here. When I talked to my grandmother and my grandfather, it was yes ma'am yes sir, no sir. And I noticed that with these guys, they don't have that form of respect, you know. I think it really forms at home, and I thank my upbringing for that part. I didn't lose those traits of respect, you know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you come out of Job Corp and go back to Gibson.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Then what happens?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I get a job at a rostral ball company called Dewy Landry's Rostral Ball. And I was paid, what, $5.75 an hour for doing jobs like pressure water testing or going on another job and cleaning the ends of the test pipe, clean them with the deiseal and recoat them with the grease and put the cap back on.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you did that for a few years?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Did that for a few years, seeing partying and them, man they were slinging, making money, driving nice cars with the wheels, got the girls. It's kind of catchy. And I started doing that and one thing led to another, man. I'll tell you that, you know, the one with confused is the Devil, man. At that time, I'm telling you man. I take this as a beautiful learning experience.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: This might be idiotic to say, man, don't look at me that I'm crazy man but I'm telling you that God saved me by sending me here, because I was headed down a road that could've got killed, you know what I'm saying. And I've endured some hardships. I'm not regretful. I'm regretful of taking a man's life, but I'm not regretful of being in Angola man, I'm telling you, because I've learned how to be a real man and I know that I got to work for what I want.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, let's go back to that guy, who came in, I'm sure you did a little bit, a little stint in the Parish

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: A little bit yea, I did two years in the Parish.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: And then you're brought in through those gates in 24?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah, that road, you see that road that you'll came on, that road wasn't like that, it was like this. They called it a snake road. It was, I was scared to death, you looked on the side of the ravines, on that old bus I was on. I was, where the world I'm headed. I got to the gates and I got the A building, and I'm sitting down and they got the classifications and people they're categorizing where they're going to send you and I'm going t, headed to Raven, Camp D. That's where I'm headed. I was sent to Raven, man.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Looking back, can you describe that process to me? When you go back?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I was categorized. I was scared man I ain't go lying. I was scared, terrified. And you know, I cried all to the Lord man, just be with me and guide me though this journey, man, and I got to Raven. When I got here man, it was working, I'm talking about actually working where you might a weight pile, when you look outside, and you'll might the weight pile. They are had 50 dudes out there with a 20 pound of weight pile breaking their fingers. Dudes taking the razors and cutting their Achilles. That's the work that we were doing. See, now they really ain't doing nothing here, they're picking a lot of vegetables.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: And they ain't, I'm taking about we were, I can honestly say guys were healthier back then. You ain't had all these guys sick or taking these medicines and dying, dudes dying every day. You know, they had a lot of violence going on man, because the devil was running havoc here. When I first got here, I had to get a knife man. I had to. It wasn't violence, ugly dudes, pretty dudes, big dudes, crazy man, but you know, you see the change up until when Warren came, stuff revolutionized, stuff started changing.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Because the illiteracy rate was so high man, dudes didn't really know how to read and nothing. And so, out of mind, man, the devil, out of mind, you know. And I think that every day, even when I came, I didn't have my GED, and a lot of guys that was going to school at that time, they was only going to school to get out of the field. There was working, but my thing was, I'm going to get my GED. It ain't take me but 6 or 8 months to get my GED because I went in there to get it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you know, we're talking to you, because you are considered, you know, a model trusted member of the community now. When, now, you didn't start that way, so can you tell me a little bit about the transition?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Yeah, I can tell you- like, man, look, when I come, ain't a drug you couldn't get. Literally. It ain't like now though but I'm saying like when I come, it was more plentiful, you wasn't pissed and all that. There wasn't a drug you couldn't get man and you know, if you had the money, you could buy and I come- man, don't get me wrong, I come 22 was still smoking weed, and you know like about let's see, '95.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I think '96, '97, they might have started piss testing, that's when I stopped smoking weed, and a bag would cost at that time, 5 packs of camels man 5 of them, a pack of camels at that time was a dollar 80-something. So we looking at 5, that's like $80 but I was, you know, looking at man wow, instead of doing this, I got to get right man.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Myself and then I was hanging around some older guys too, always telling me, "Look, don't mess with no drug, don't mess with no cult. Don't mess with no gambling, you ain't going to get in no trouble. You know, do what you got to do, always look for better." It kind of stuck with me. It took me a while though. Had to go, how always, you got to get into something man.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: So I had one incident, I got a job in the kitchen once I come out of Raven. I got a job in the kitchen, working in the baking area. The guy said, "Man, yeast man, we make some good beer man." Real yeast in the kitchen so, wow, me, I'm bold and man risks, I don't take no risks, you know.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: And I say "well, I'm going to make beer in my box, man." In my lock box, 2, 5 gallon buckets. Every two days, we make beer. Sort of unfortunately, this day, Freeman walking down the said, "Smell like a distillery in here." Because I'm feeling up the bottles to get them to dudes in other dorm. Man, the man walked back there. So I leave my bed, I light some, we have buck cans by our bed right.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I light some paper in the buck can, to kind of like kill the scent, they don't do nothing, and the man walking up the hall find my bed. I'm sitting in the TV room, he calling my name and "Allen Pharr, Allen Pharr." I get to my bed, he said "Look, open up this box." But I got all the bottles on the floor, he sees all them bottles.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I said "Look Mr. Tiller. I said, "Look Mr. Tiller, I said who you about to knock off man?" I said, "Man, I got some beer, want me to go pull it out in the." "Oh no." he hit the beep. It was almost shift change, so me and the people, the people that's coming on for the night shift, they come down.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Man they locked me up, I told them, "Man that's on at night." He said "Look, I can cut you lose. I know you're going to Camp J." That's where all them drugs, and them knives at so. I said, "What drugs and knives, man." Because, you know I got to do stuff prison. So, I go to the block. I get sentenced to the block. Man, I got to tighten up. I can't, I'm already in trouble doing a life sentences. So, on my own, I kind of like turned it around, you know, after that instance.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How far into your sentence did that happen?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: It's alright I got '88? Like about 5 years into my sentence, like 5 years running around. At that time, see, we had the plan here. We were able to breeze twice a week and you know, let me see, we were getting 7.50 a breeze. So that's 14 dollars a week plus whatever we was getting from home or whatever. So you know, it was like man, it was crazy man.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: So, literally I took it upon myself to say well, man you got to make a change man for the better literally. And that's what I did man. I turned it around man, from one job to the next, I said well I'm get trustee man, I can't be get trustee. I did it. I worked. My first time on the trustee board. I went on the trustee board full-time before I made it, you know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you describe your typical day here now?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Oh, my typical day is now is like, well I just moved, man, I'm glad you said that man. I was at Cypress 4 and I just moved into Ash 1. That's the first unit on the East shelf, Ash, so you got Ash, Mag, Cypress, and Spruce. Spruce all the way on the end. They call that "the ghetto" Spruce, but Ash, we call that the "White House" Because like other than Pastor Waters, like. He lives in the, you met Gillam? George Gillam? He lives in Mag, but they call Ash pretty much the White House. I moved to Ash 1 and man I'm talking about it's so quiet and its man, serenity, but the dorm that I was in, it was an old Trustee dorm Cypress 4 right?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: But guys, man, I'm telling you it's, not to be critical, I'm 53 years old man and you know, nothing has been handed to me, and I can honestly say that I have a name when you say, I don't think. Did you hear them this morning when they said, "What do you call first?" You see that little. Who did well, I'm known. You know, I'm known because I made myself known in a positive way.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I work at, let me tell you where I work at right now. I was working at old elementary school, pre-k school, middle school and the high school in West Louisiana Parish, 4 days a week.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were you doing there?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: We was cutting grass and doing janitorial work 4 days a week and unfortunately, they shut the crew down because they didn't renew the contract. Angola had a contract with them and you know I was working out there and when they shut that crew down, they put me on the kitchen truck.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: So, a guy got into it at the control center. The control center is where they keep all the guns and everything. It's a high risk area so when that guy lost his job, I heard it in the grapevine. I said, "Oh man I'm going to get that job." You know, I have Mr. Hollis Milton, Mr. Milton Hollis, he is superintendent of the Western Louisiana Parish School Board. And he gave us a letter of recommendation on how good we worked and efficient that every time they call on us man, we do it. It was like an 8 man crew.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: And you know man, I try to do my thing to where people will be appreciated. Man, I tell you, it don't take much man to do wrong. It takes so much effort to do the right thing man. It takes a lot of effort man and that's how it is. So right now, I got a good job at the center, but getting back to where I was living in, Cypress 4, you got guys who are really not working. Trustees, this an all Trustee dorm.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I was living in Bay 1, the windows full of cobwebs man, they got dudes they call dorm audits, they're supposed to clean up every day and dudes are so disrespectful man, you know? It's just do things idiotically. So I just made it up on my mind. I'm not going to get in trouble with no guys man, it ain't worth that. I'm just move out of there and that's what I did. Thank the Lord man.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What, aside from that job, what other organizations are you active with here or have you been active?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Well, I've been active with the Lifer's club and I'm affiliated with a club called Dale Carnegie right now, DC Lyons. I'm affiliated with them, but I've got my Anger Management, Mis-management, substance abuse, I got my GED, you know and Clubs, I don't too much. The only reason I'm affiliated with DC is because I got a couple of friends that's really into it and so political man, and you know, I don't think.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: See, not, but Norris Henderson, do you remember Norris? Norris, that guy there man, he was really a go-getter meaning that when Norris was here, you had Texas Southern, Prairie View, LSU, and a whole lot of other institutions coming in here, speaking and you know, learning how this place was revolutionizing other institutions but guys had to put forth the effort. You know, because like all other institutions, there's a negative and a positive, you just got to tap into the one you want, you know?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, let me ask you a difficult question because you know this project is about life without parole and it's difficult because to me, it would seem a very painful thing to continuously deal with. When you think about your own life, you surely must have time where you realize that it's likely that you may never leave here. How do you cope with that? How do you make sense of that?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Man, every day, I could literally say, man I earned this, but my tears don't roll out my eye. But I'm telling you man that God is my shelter bro, for real, and you know, since I come here, I learned that this is not a thing of being a churchy person. What keeps me because before come here, we used to have church in the classroom or in the kitchen? Now they got a Cathedral everywhere, man. But that's not the thing.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: See, a lot of people get stuck up, even on the outside with a program how things are supposed to go ain't the way it is. Not in my reading and I've accepted Jesus, my lord and savior man. I'm telling you if I were to die right now as we speak, I knew that I'm going home because I changed the person I used to be to a God fearing man and the reason I want to be free again is to tell some youngster to do the right thing, that's the reason, and hope that to have a kid and raising yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Fair enough. And I think that's a very good answer. This is also a difficult question. So, it's been 30- you've spend 30 years being punished for this charge. How much punishment is enough punishment?

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: For a first offender, man, a guy that's never been in trouble man, no criminal record, that's amazing to me, to the way it is. I got a guy named Wolf that the Supreme Court granted him, he the one of the juveniles that got, been down 52 years as a juvenile. He's still down there on Spruce.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: I'm 31 years. Man, how long it is for a man to get out 53 still walking here, in good shape, he work at the. What I'm saying is how long it is for a guy to be incarcerated and do his time, especially if he's meeting all the programs. If he is, why can't receive we can let him out again and give him another chance.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: If he mess up again, I can understand it but mainly for first offender, I'm a first offender and I can only speak for me. I can't be critical of the people, and guess what? I've seen guys been here 6 times at Angola, they're gone.

transcript.speaker: Allen
transcript.content: Man, I've seen some guys who come here two, three times gone. So, you know, the figmentation in my mind is saying, "Wow, it ain't for everybody." You know, everybody got time, and I've seen since, right now, it's the most guys have been going home man, you know, it's changing. And I tell you God is in control man.
